title: 115_hr856
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Putting Our Veterans Back to Work Act of 2017" and includes a table of contents. TITLE I--RENEWING OUR VOW TO HIRE HEROES
- Reauthorizes veterans retraining assistance program
- Extends authority for rehabilitation and vocational benefits for Armed Forces members with severe injuries or illnesses
- Extends rehabilitation programs for individuals who have exhausted unemployment benefits
- Reauthorizes veterans' training, mentoring, and placement program

TITLE II--BUILDING ON OUR VOW TO HIRE HEROES Sec. 201-203 of the bill focus on creating employment opportunities for veterans through a unified portal, grants for hiring veterans as first responders, and giving preference to veteran employment in Federal contract awards. This is part of the broader effort outlined in Title I to renew commitments to hiring veterans, including reauthorizing the Veterans Retraining Assistance Program. (a) Extension of the VOW to Hire Heroes Act of 2011 until December 31, 2020.
(b) Increasing the number of eligible veterans to receive assistance:
    - 50,000 during fiscal years 2017, 2018, and 2019
    - 50,000 from October 1, 2019, to December 31, 2020. The VOW to Hire Heroes Act of 2011 is extended until December 31, 2020. Amendments include retraining assistance provided by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs limited to 12 months and a report update due by December 31, 2021. A conforming amendment removes the deadline of October 1, 2013. SEC. 102 extends the authority of the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to provide rehabilitation and vocational benefits to members of the Armed Forces with severe injuries or illnesses. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs' authority to provide benefits under the Wounded Warrior Act is extended until December 31, 2020. A report on these benefits must be submitted to the appropriate committees of Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The extension of rehabilitation programs for individuals who have exhausted unemployment benefits under state law is amended to March 31, 2020. The reauthorization of the collaborative veterans' training, mentoring, and placement program includes appropriations for fiscal years 2018-2019 and 2020-2021. Additionally, a unified employment portal for veterans is established under the Building on Our Vow to Hire Heroes initiative. SEC. 201. UNIFIED EMPLOYMENT PORTAL FOR VETERANS. The Secretary will develop a single, unified Federal web-based employment portal for veterans, in collaboration with other Federal agencies. SEC. 202. Grants to hire veterans as first responders. The Secretary of Homeland Security will award grants to hire veterans as firefighters and the Attorney General will award grants to hire veterans as law enforcement officers. Priority will be given to veterans who served on active duty after September 11, 2001. $250,000,000 is authorized for this purpose. SEC. 203. Employment of veterans as evaluation factor in federal contracts. Executive agencies must consider favorably the employment of veterans as an evaluation factor in contracts valued at or above $25,000,000. The head of each agency must consider favorably the employment of veterans as an evaluation factor in contracts valued at or above $25,000,000. Contractors must have at least five percent of their workforce composed of veterans. The Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council must amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation within 180 days to implement the employment of veterans as an evaluation factor in contracts valued at or above $25,000,000.
